problems.title: E-commerce Shopping Cart Abandonment Epidemic Costing Retailers Billions in Lost Revenue
problems.description: Online shopping cart abandonment represents one of the most persistent and costly challenges in e-commerce, with abandonment rates consistently exceeding 70% worldwide. This translates to massive lost revenue opportunities—for every $100 a customer intends to spend, approximately $70 never converts to actual sales. The problem is multi-faceted: unexpected costs at checkout (shipping, taxes, fees) cause 48% of abandonments, while mandatory account creation drives away 24% of shoppers. Complicated checkout processes, security concerns, and lack of payment options further contribute to the crisis. The situation is worsening: IRP Commerce reports a negative trend in global conversion efficiency, with even small percentage declines having significant revenue impact at scale. Mobile commerce exacerbates the problem, with mobile cart abandonment rates typically 10-15% higher than desktop due to smaller screens and friction in mobile payment processes. Additionally, high return rates compound the challenge—an estimated 19.3% of online sales will be returned in 2025, meaning even completed transactions often fail to generate net revenue. The e-commerce customer journey involves an average of 6-8 touchpoints before purchase, with each representing a potential abandonment point. Retailers implementing cart recovery strategies (abandoned cart emails, retargeting) recover only 3-5% of abandoned carts on average, leaving the vast majority of potential revenue uncaptured.
problems.summary: E-commerce cart abandonment rates exceed 70% globally, with unexpected costs, complicated checkouts, and mobile friction being primary causes, resulting in billions in lost revenue that recovery strategies only marginally address.

problems.title: Exploding Customer Acquisition Costs Threatening E-commerce Profitability and Growth
problems.description: E-commerce businesses face an existential challenge as customer acquisition costs (CAC) have skyrocketed, fundamentally threatening unit economics and profitability. The average CAC surged by 222% between 2013 and 2024, rising from $9 to $29 per customer. This dramatic increase stems from multiple converging factors: digital advertising saturation with major platforms like Facebook and Google seeing declining ad effectiveness, iOS privacy changes (App Tracking Transparency) reducing targeting precision, increased competition as more retailers shift online, and rising cost-per-click across all major advertising channels. The problem is particularly acute for direct-to-consumer (DTC) brands that relied heavily on Facebook and Instagram advertising, with many reporting CAC increases of 50-100% since 2021. As a result, many e-commerce businesses now spend more to acquire a customer than they earn from that customer's first purchase, forcing reliance on repeat purchases and lifetime value that may never materialize. Retailers expect shoppers to prioritize price over brand loyalty in 2026 as inflation tightens budgets, making customer retention even more challenging. PitchBook's 2026 outlook predicts a K-shaped economy deepening the divide between retail's haves and have-nots—companies with established customer bases will thrive while those dependent on acquisition will struggle. The venture capital pullback from DTC brands reflects market recognition that the paid acquisition model is increasingly unsustainable.
